DOC.HEAD: Latest Developments in Eastern Europe
With PM-Romania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a look at major developments in Eastern Europe:

A Yugoslav traveler reports two people were killed during weekend demonstrations against hard-line President Nicolae Ceausescu, the largest anti-government demonstrations in two years. The country closes its border with Yugolavia to all but official traffic, and security is reported tightened at the Hungarian border following reports of violent weekend demonstrations. Hungarian legislators report tanks patrolling the major Romanian city of Timisoara and nearby Arad, the sites of demonstrations. Romanian emigres report further unrest in the city of Brasov, site of a major uprising in 1987.

The Communist Party chief, Karel Urbanek, is quoted as saying his party will probably try to form a coalition with other leftist parties before free elections planned next year. The party daily, Rude Pravo, prints a front-page apology for previous articles that attacked such reformers as Vaclav Havel and Alexander Dubcek. Foreign Minister Jiri Dienstbier prepares to travel to Moscow on Wednesday for discussions on the possible withdrawal from Czechoslovakia of about 80,000 Soviet troops installed after the invasion that crushed a 1968 reform movement.

The Communists and opposition factions resume talks on the country's future. Angry protesters demanding a part in the negotiations disrupt the session's first hour by banging on the windows and shouting through bullhorns. The forum agrees to meet each Monday and opens talks to five more groups.

About 160,000 workers stage a half-hour ``warning'' strike in the republic of Montenegro to pressure the Communist government to adopt urgent measures to contain hyperinflation. Premier Ante Markovic proposes the introduction of a new convertible currency unit at a key parliamentary session that is to decide an economic and political reform package.
